shortcuts: Divisibility of 7, 11, 13: Difference between the last 3 digits and the remaining digits must be 0 or divisible by the number.
Sum of first 'n' natural numbers: $n(n+1)/2$.
Finding Unit Digit: Focus only on the last digit and use cyclicity of 4 for powers.
common_mistakes: Confusing 'Prime Numbers' with 'Odd Numbers' (remember: 2 is the only even prime).
Ignoring the remainder 0 in cyclicity (if power is divisible by 4, use $x^4$ not $x^0$).
Treating 1 as a prime number (1 is neither prime nor composite).

shortcuts: Product Rule: $HCF \times LCM = Product\ of\ two\ numbers$.
HCF of Fractions: $HCF\ of\ Numerators / LCM\ of\ Denominators$.
LCM of Fractions: $LCM\ of\ Numerators / HCF\ of\ Denominators$.
common_mistakes: Finding LCM when the question asks for the 'Greatest' number (HCF) that divides.
Forgetting to add/subtract the remainder at the final step in 'Remainder' type problems.
Not simplifying fractions to their lowest terms before finding HCF/LCM.

shortcuts: V-BODMAS: Follow strictly: Vinculum, Bracket, Of, Division, Multiplication, Addition, Subtraction.
Digital Sum: Use the sum of digits to eliminate options in heavy multiplication/division.
Square root of perfect squares: Look at the unit digit (e.g., if it ends in 1, the root ends in 1 or 9).
common_mistakes: Treating 'Of' as a simple multiplication and doing 'Division' before it.
Calculation errors due to lack of approximation when options are far apart.
Incorrectly applying $(a+b)^2$ formulas to cubical expressions.

shortcuts: Deviation Method: Assume a mean and find how much each value deviates from it to save time on large sums.
Average of first 'n' odd numbers is always 'n'.
Average of first 'n' even numbers is 'n + 1'.
common_mistakes: Calculating the average of speeds by simply adding and dividing by 2 (Must use Harmonic Mean).
Including the wrong number of terms (e.g., counting 1 to 10 as 9 terms instead of 10).
Forgetting to update the 'Total Number' after a person joins or leaves a group.

shortcuts: Successive % Change: $A + B + (AB/100)$. Use for area changes or consecutive discounts.
Product Consistency: If price increases by 25% (1/4), consumption must decrease by 20% (1/5) to keep expenditure same.
common_mistakes: Applying % change on the new value instead of the original 'Base' value.
Confusing 'Percentage Points' with 'Percentage Change'.
Calculating 20% of 80 as 20 instead of 16.

shortcuts: CP is always 100%: If profit is 20%, SP = 120% of CP. If loss is 10%, SP = 90% of CP.
Dishonest Dealer: $Profit\% = [Error / (True\ Value - Error)] \times 100$.
When CP of 'x' articles = SP of 'y' articles, $Profit/Loss\% = [(x-y)/y] \times 100$.
common_mistakes: Calculating Profit/Loss % on Selling Price (SP) instead of Cost Price (CP).
Applying the wrong base when multiple profits are involved (Chain rule).
Assuming SP is the same as MP (Marked Price) when no discount is mentioned.

shortcuts: The Relation: $MP / CP = (100 + P\%) / (100 - D\%)$. Extremely useful for SSC exams.
Single Equivalent Discount: For $d1$ and $d2$, it is $d1 + d2 - (d1 \times d2 / 100)$.
common_mistakes: Applying discount on CP instead of MP (Marked Price).
Adding successive discounts directly (e.g., 10% + 10% is 19%, not 20%).
Confusing 'Discount' with 'Loss'.

shortcuts: SI: Interest is same every year. $SI = (P \times R \times T) / 100$.
CI: Difference between CI and SI for 2 years = $P(R/100)^2$.
CI: Amount doubles in 'n' years? It will become 4 times in '2n' years.
common_mistakes: Forgetting to divide the Rate by 2 and multiply Time by 2 for 'Half-Yearly' CI.
Calculating CI on the Principal only (CI is interest on interest).
Confusing 'Amount' (P+I) with 'Interest' (I) in the final answer.

shortcuts: If $A:B = 2:3$ and $B:C = 4:5$, then $A:B:C = (2\times4) : (3\times4) : (3\times5)$.
Mean Proportional of a and b is $\sqrt{ab}$.
Third Proportional of a and b is $b^2/a$.
common_mistakes: Comparing ratios with different units (e.g., meters to kilometers).
Assuming the parts of a ratio are the actual values (always multiply by a constant 'x').
Mixing up the order (e.g., writing B:A when the question asks for A:B).

shortcuts: L.C.M Method: Assume Total Work = LCM of days. This converts days into 'Efficiency' (Units/day).
Man-Days Formula: $(M1 \times D1 \times H1) / W1 = (M2 \times D2 \times H2) / W2$.
Efficiency: If A is twice as good as B, he takes half the time.
common_mistakes: Adding 'Days' directly instead of 'Efficiency'.
Not accounting for people leaving mid-work.
Forgetting that 'Work' is inversely proportional to 'Time'.

shortcuts: Alligation Rule: (Quantity of Cheaper) / (Quantity of Dearer) = (CP of Dearer - Mean Price) / (Mean Price - CP of Cheaper).
Replacement Formula: Final Concentration = $Initial\ (1 - x/V)^n$, where x is replaced volume and V is total volume.
common_mistakes: Using Selling Price (SP) in the alligation cross instead of Cost Price (CP). All three values must be CP.
Mixing up the ratios (putting the Cheaper quantity under the Dearer side).

shortcuts: Inlet pipe = Positive efficiency (+); Outlet/Leak pipe = Negative efficiency (-).
If a pipe fills in 'x' hours and another empties in 'y' hours, net work = $(xy) / (y - x)$.
common_mistakes: Forgetting to treat the 'Leak' as a negative value in the total sum.
Miscalculating the time when pipes are opened alternately (Odd/Even hour logic).

shortcuts: Distance is Constant: Speed is inversely proportional to Time ($S_1/S_2 = T_2/T_1$).
Late/Early Concept: $Distance = [Product\ of\ Speeds / Diff\ of\ Speeds] \times [Diff\ in\ Time / 60]$.
common_mistakes: Mixing km/hr with seconds. Always check units first!
Average speed error: Do not use $(S_1 + S_2)/2$ unless time intervals are identical.

shortcuts: Crossing a point/pole: Distance = Length of Train.
Crossing a Bridge/Platform: Distance = (Length of Train + Length of Platform).
Relative Speed: Subtract speeds for same direction; Add for opposite.
common_mistakes: Not converting speed to m/s when the train length is in meters.
Neglecting the length of the *second* train when they cross each other.

shortcuts: Downstream Speed (D) = $u + v$; Upstream Speed (U) = $u - v$.
Speed of Boat in still water ($u$) = $(D + U) / 2$.
Speed of Stream ($v$) = $(D - U) / 2$.
common_mistakes: Confusing 'Upstream' (against flow) with 'Downstream' (with flow).
Incorrectly assuming the speed of the boat in still water is the same as its speed downstream.

shortcuts: The age difference between two people remains constant forever.
Ratio Method: If the ratio is $2:3$ now and $3:4$ in 5 years, the 1 unit difference = 5 years.
common_mistakes: Applying the time gap to only one person instead of both.
Getting confused between 'x years ago' (Subtract) and 'x years hence' (Add).

shortcuts: Combination (Selection): Use $nCr$ when order doesn't matter (e.g., forming a committee).
Permutation (Arrangement): Use $nPr$ when order matters (e.g., arranging letters in a word).
Circular Permutation: $(n - 1)!$.
common_mistakes: Using Permutation where only Selection (Combination) was needed.
Forgetting to divide by $r!$ for identical items (e.g., repeating letters in a word).

shortcuts: Probability = (Favorable Outcomes) / (Total Outcomes).
$P(Event) + P(Not\ Event) = 1$.
In 'At least' problems, it is often easier to calculate '1 - Probability of None'.
common_mistakes: Calculating a probability greater than 1 (Mathematically impossible).
Miscounting the sample space (e.g., 2 dice = 36 outcomes, not 12).

shortcuts: If sides of a 2D shape increase by $x\%$, area increases by $[2x + x^2/100]\%$.
Radius of Incircle of equilateral triangle = $a / (2\sqrt{3})$.
Volume of any prism = Base Area $\times$ Height.
common_mistakes: Confusing 'Curved Surface Area' with 'Total Surface Area' (which includes the base/top).
Forgetting to cube the units for Volume ($cm^3$) or square them for Area ($cm^2$).

shortcuts: To find % growth: $(Final - Initial) / Initial \times 100$.
Pie Chart: $1\% = 3.6\ degrees$. To convert degrees to %, divide by 3.6.
Scanning: Use 'Visual Estimation' to eliminate options before doing heavy calculation.
common_mistakes: Misreading the units in the graph legend (e.g., 'Values in Lakhs').
Wasting time on one complex calculation when the rest of the set is easy.
Picking the value for the wrong year due to misaligned columns.
